project_metadata.paper_title: Identifying accurate artefact morphological ranges using optimal linear estimation: Method validation, case studies, and code
project_metadata.journal: Journal of Archaeological Science, Vol. 162, Article 105921
project_metadata.research_context: Investigates whether optimal linear estimation (OLE) modelling can accurately identify the upper and lower limits of artefact morphological ranges from fragmentary archaeological records. Validates the method using replica stone tool assemblages with known complete distributions, then applies it to lithic, ceramic, and metal archaeological case studies spanning human, hominin, and non-human primate material culture.

evidence.evidence_text: 500 replica Acheulean handaxes produced over 18 months on British flint for experimental functional studies
evidence.verbatim_quote: 500 replica Acheulean handaxes were produced by Key and Lycett (2017) on British flint over the course of 18 months for use in a series of experimental functional studies

evidence.evidence_text: 45 replica Early Archaic points produced for validation testing, consistent with Thebes cluster style
evidence.verbatim_quote: we also investigated morphometric data from 45 replica Early Archaic points (Fig. 2). The Early Archaic period in North America occurred during the Early Holocene. These points, consistent with the Early Archaic side-notched 'Thebes cluster' style (Justice 1987), have not been used in any other published studies

evidence.evidence_text: Replica handaxe assemblage subsampled at rates of 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% for validation tests
evidence.verbatim_quote: The replica handaxe assemblage was randomly subsampled at rates of 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% relative to the total number of records in the assemblage

evidence.evidence_text: 1000 iterations performed for each subsampling percentage and k value combination
evidence.verbatim_quote: One thousand iterations of each process were performed for all subsampling percentages and k, and results were presented as median values across all iterations

evidence.evidence_text: Perfect CI coverage equals 0.95 (1-alpha with alpha=0.05)
evidence.verbatim_quote: A perfect coverage would be one that is equal to 1-alpha (with alpha of 0.05 used here). Coverage below 0.95 (0–0.94) indicates that OLE tends to underestimate the given morphological range limit

evidence.evidence_text: Ten case studies investigated covering lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts from humans, extinct hominins, and non-human primates
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions (Fig. 2). Case studies cover tools produced or used by Holocene humans (Homo sapiens), Early-to-Late Pleistocene hominins (H. erectus, H. heidelbergensis s.l., Homo sapiens) and bearded capuchins (Sapajus libidinosus)

evidence.evidence_text: Ten archaeological case studies with diverse sample sizes: Old Park flakes (n=173), Boxgrove handaxes (n=254), Olduvai cleavers (n=134), Sibudu bipolar cores (n=131), capuchin flakes (n=31), copper socketed tang points (n=93), Middle Historic bowls (n=1466), and Neolithic pottery (small dataset)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions (Fig. 2). Case studies cover tools produced or used by Holocene humans (Homo sapiens), Early-to-Late Pleistocene hominins (H. erectus, H. heidelbergensis s.l., Homo sapiens) and bearded capuchins (Sapajus libidinosus)

consolidation_metadata.granularity_available: Individual case study sample sizes documented in Methods section 2.4
consolidation_metadata.rationale: All 8 items had identical support pattern {C006} and represent case study sample sizes assessed together as evidence of methodological diversity

evidence.evidence_text: Paleoindian points from North America spanning ~13,500-10,000 calBP including Clovis (n=810), Eastern Clovis (n=228), Folsom (n=179), and Midland (n=64)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We chose early Paleoindian lithic points from North America (~13,500 - 10,000 calBP) as they display a series of defined lanceolate forms that overlap morphologically (e.g. Buchanan et al., 2018; Eren et al., 2022). Here, we focus on Clovis (incl. Eastern), Folsom and Midland points only

evidence.evidence_text: 344 geometric microliths from phase A and 390 from phase B at Cueva de la Cocina
evidence.verbatim_quote: All in all, this leaves us with a total of 344 geometrics for phase A and 390 for phase B

evidence.evidence_text: Validation tests show median TE values provide accurate estimates for true upper/lower range limits across multiple k values and sampling percentages
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is clear that varying k values and subsampling percentages impact the accuracy of the OLE estimates. Further, it is evident that for each variable there are median modelled results providing accurate estimates of the 'true' upper or lower range limits observed in the replica assemblages

evidence.evidence_text: Median CI coverage under 50% sampling condition close to 0.95, while 5% sampling approximately 0.62
evidence.verbatim_quote: the median value under the 50% sampling condition is close to 0.95 (i.e., 1-α), while for the 5% sampling condition it is approximately 0.62, indicating that sample percentages below 50% of the total sample underestimate range limits

evidence.evidence_text: 20% sampling percentage returned median CI coverage values above 0.82
evidence.verbatim_quote: A sampling percentage of 20% still returned median values above 0.82, indicating broadly acceptable estimates

evidence.evidence_text: For n=45 archaic point assemblage, all sampling percentages returned median values ≥0.8
evidence.verbatim_quote: For the n = 45 replica archaic point assemblage, all sampling percentages returned median values ≥ 0.8, and there were no clear trends whereby greater sampling percentages equated to greater estimate accuracy

evidence.evidence_text: k=5 less likely to return CI intervals that underestimate range limits
evidence.verbatim_quote: For all, it is clear that k = 5 is less likely to return confidence intervals that underestimate range limits

evidence.evidence_text: Minimum range estimates display higher accuracy than maximum range estimates
evidence.verbatim_quote: Fig. 4 demonstrates that for both tool types, estimates for the minimum range limit of variables display higher accuracy than models estimating maximum range limits

evidence.evidence_text: Copper socketed tang point breadth range extended by 62.9%
evidence.verbatim_quote: For example, OLE increased the n = 93 copper socketed tang point breadth range by 62.9% (Table 5)

evidence.evidence_text: Clovis assemblage (n=810) experienced smallest range expansion (all ≤12.2%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: For example, out of the four Paleoindian point types, the Clovis assemblage was by far the largest (n = 810), and experienced the smallest range expansion percentage across all investigated attributes (all were ≤12.2%; Table 6; Fig. 7)

evidence.evidence_text: Boxgrove handaxe elongation range extended by 36.2% and refinement by 38.3%
evidence.verbatim_quote: The substantial Boxgrove assemblage (n = 254), for example, estimated there to be considerably more elongated and less refined handaxes made by this H. heidelbergensis s.l. population, with range extensions of 36.2% and 38.3% being returned, respectively

evidence.evidence_text: Middle Historic bowl rim diameter extended by 40.7% despite largest sample (n=1466)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The rim diameter of the Middle Historic bowls, which display the largest sample in any case study (n = 1466), is another example of OLE creating a considerable range extension (40.7%) in spite of the substantial sample size (Table 5)

evidence.evidence_text: Midland Paleoindian point mass only increased by 5.1% despite n=64
evidence.verbatim_quote: Alternatively, the mass-range of the Midland Paleoindian type only increased by 5.1%, despite the assemblage only consisting of 64 artefacts (Table 6)

evidence.evidence_text: Capuchin flake mass extended by 56%, while length, breadth, thickness extensions 22.3%, 21.2%, 26%
evidence.verbatim_quote: Capuchin flake mass (n = 31), for example, was extended by 56%, while flake length, breadth and thickness extensions were more limited – albeit not low – at 22.3, 21.2 and 26%, respectively (Table 5)

evidence.evidence_text: Duplicate removal had little-to-no impact on OLE morphometric estimates for geometric microliths
evidence.verbatim_quote: The additional resampling procedures undertaken for the geometric microliths reveal the removal of duplicate records to have little-to-no impact on OLE morphometric estimates, and in turn, range extensions

evidence.evidence_text: Sibudu bipolar cores showed limited range extensions (3.3-17.2%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The Sibudu bipolar core's more limited range extensions (3.3–17.2 %) result from there being multiple tightly constrained records at the upper and lower limits of each variable

evidence.evidence_text: Eastern Clovis maximum length extended from 151mm to 211mm (60mm increase)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Prior to the present paper there was a 75 mm difference between the largest evidenced Eastern Clovis point (151 mm) and the largest Clovis point (231 mm). The OLE estimates reduced this difference substantially, with the modelled Clovis point maximum length being 243 mm, while the estimated maximum size of Eastern Clovis points is now 211 mm, 60 mm longer than previously thought

evidence.evidence_text: Old Park flake mass range extended from 0.2-40.2g to approximately 0.06-55g
evidence.verbatim_quote: For example, flake mass – at least for the technological strategies discovered so far (as there could be others [e.g., Sharon, 2010]) – should no longer be considered to vary from 0.2 to 40.2 g, but instead likely ranges from ~0.06 to 55 g

evidence.evidence_text: Boxgrove PC1 and PC2 shape variation predicted to increase by 47% and 24% respectively
evidence.verbatim_quote: Indeed, PC1 and PC2 are predicted to increase by 47% and 24%, respectively

evidence.evidence_text: All analyses undertaken in R version 4.3.0
evidence.verbatim_quote: All analyses were undertaken in 'R' version 4.3.0

claims.claim_text: OLE modelling provides broadly accurate estimates for the true morphological range of artefact assemblages
claims.verbatim_quote: Validation tests demonstrate OLE to be capable of providing broadly accurate estimates for the true morphological range of artefact assemblages

claims.claim_text: OLE can be applied across lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts produced by humans, extinct hominins, and non-human primates
claims.verbatim_quote: Using morphometric data from lithic, ceramic, and metal archaeological case studies, we then identify how much further the upper and lower form limits of these artefact types would have been in the past

claims.claim_text: Replica artefact assemblages with known complete distributions provide appropriate validation contexts for testing OLE
claims.verbatim_quote: To circumnavigate this issue, we use modern assemblages of replica artefacts as this allows random subsamples from a much larger, known distribution of artefacts to be created. These subsamples are then used in an analogous way to the fragmentary portions of artefact records discovered by archaeologists

claims.claim_text: OLE estimate accuracy increases relative to the percentage of the total assemblage used
claims.verbatim_quote: Estimate accuracy increases relative to the percentage of the total assemblage used and the method is shown to function well using as few as five records (k) from an assemblage

claims.claim_text: Perfect CI coverage equals 0.95 (1-alpha), with values below indicating underestimation and above indicating overestimation
claims.verbatim_quote: A perfect coverage would be one that is equal to 1-alpha (with alpha of 0.05 used here). Coverage below 0.95 (0–0.94) indicates that OLE tends to underestimate the given morphological range limit

claims.claim_text: Ten diverse case studies demonstrate how OLE influences understanding of archaeological records under varied assemblage conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions

claims.claim_text: A k value of 5 is less likely to return confidence intervals that underestimate morphological range limits
claims.verbatim_quote: For all, it is clear that k = 5 is less likely to return confidence intervals that underestimate range limits

claims.claim_text: Minimum range limit estimates display higher accuracy than maximum range limit estimates
claims.verbatim_quote: Fig. 4 demonstrates that for both tool types, estimates for the minimum range limit of variables display higher accuracy than models estimating maximum range limits

claims.claim_text: Smaller assemblages (n=45) can still produce broadly acceptable OLE estimates with median CI coverage values ≥0.8
claims.verbatim_quote: For the n = 45 replica archaic point assemblage, all sampling percentages returned median values ≥ 0.8, and there were no clear trends whereby greater sampling percentages equated to greater estimate accuracy

claims.claim_text: OLE extends artefact morphological ranges in all investigated case studies, with extensions varying from marginal to substantial
claims.verbatim_quote: In all instances artefact ranges were extended by the OLE estimates. In some instances additions were marginal, for others ranges were extended considerably

claims.claim_text: Copper socketed tang point breadth experienced substantial range extension (62.9%) due to relatively low tail-end densities
claims.verbatim_quote: For example, OLE increased the n = 93 copper socketed tang point breadth range by 62.9%

claims.claim_text: Larger artefact samples generally result in more limited OLE range extensions
claims.verbatim_quote: out of the four Paleoindian point types, the Clovis assemblage was by far the largest (n = 810), and experienced the smallest range expansion percentage across all investigated attributes (all were ≤12.2%)

claims.claim_text: OLE can substantially alter previously recognised morphological differences or similarities between artefact groups
claims.verbatim_quote: At times, previously recognised differences or similarities between groups of artefacts were severely reduced or reversed

claims.claim_text: Boxgrove handaxes likely display considerably more diverse forms than previously recognised, with shape variation (PC1, PC2) predicted to increase by 47% and 24%
claims.verbatim_quote: Indeed, PC1 and PC2 are predicted to increase by 47% and 24%, respectively. This does not mean that Boxgrove does not display strong ovate central tendencies... but rather, there are likely far more diverse forms being produced by these H. heidelbergensis s.l. individuals than previously recognised

claims.claim_text: Mass-produced ceramics can still display substantial OLE range extensions despite standardised production processes
claims.verbatim_quote: The rim diameter of the Middle Historic bowls, which display the largest sample in any case study (n = 1466), is another example of OLE creating a considerable range extension (40.7%) in spite of the substantial sample size

claims.claim_text: Duplicate record removal has little-to-no impact on OLE morphometric estimates and range extensions
claims.verbatim_quote: The additional resampling procedures undertaken for the geometric microliths reveal the removal of duplicate records to have little-to-no impact on OLE morphometric estimates, and in turn, range extensions

claims.claim_text: Sibudu bipolar cores show limited OLE range extensions (3.3-17.2%) due to tightly constrained records at morphological limits, suggesting near-accurate representation of core variability
claims.verbatim_quote: The Sibudu bipolar core's more limited range extensions (3.3–17.2 %) result from there being multiple tightly constrained records at the upper and lower limits of each variable. This suggests the artefact sample to provide a near-accurate representation of the core variability produced by these Middle Stone Age humans

claims.claim_text: OLE substantially reduces the previously recognised size difference between Clovis and Eastern Clovis points (from 75mm to 32mm difference in maximum length)
claims.verbatim_quote: Prior to the present paper there was a 75 mm difference between the largest evidenced Eastern Clovis point (151 mm) and the largest Clovis point (231 mm). The OLE estimates reduced this difference substantially, with the modelled Clovis point maximum length being 243 mm, while the estimated maximum size of Eastern Clovis points is now 211 mm, 60 mm longer than previously thought

claims.claim_text: Old Park flake mass range should be revised from 0.2-40.2g to approximately 0.06-55g based on OLE modelling
claims.verbatim_quote: flake mass – at least for the technological strategies discovered so far (as there could be others [e.g., Sharon, 2010]) – should no longer be considered to vary from 0.2 to 40.2 g, but instead likely ranges from ~0.06 to 55 g

claims.claim_text: OLE estimates should be treated as theoretically robust predictions contingent on model assumptions being met, not as proof that extreme morphologies were definitively created in the past
claims.verbatim_quote: As with any modelling process, the present results should only be treated as theoretically robust predictions (when the model assumptions are met). In addition, the use of OLE does not mean that these extreme morphologies were created in the past, they instead represent the best available estimate for a range limit given the artefacts available

claims.claim_text: The optimal number of records (k) to enter into the OLE model is approximately 5-10, consistent with prior temporal-based research recommendations
claims.verbatim_quote: The optimal number of records (k) entered into the model is approximately 5–10 (with a compromise of k = 8 appearing suitable)

claims.claim_text: Weibull-form distributions are a reasonable assumption for most cultural artefacts governed by cultural evolutionary pressures
claims.verbatim_quote: This is a reasonable inference for most cultural artefacts governed by cultural evolutionary pressures, where specific object-forms are preferentially selected for, but variation is introduced to a sample by external factors including differing functional (incl. ecological) conditions, raw material factors, and drift mechanisms

claims.claim_text: OLE estimates are only impacted by the distribution of data at the upper or lower limits of the phenomenon's known range, making it suitable for artefacts with complex central distributions
claims.verbatim_quote: One advantage of the method is, therefore, that estimates are only impacted by the distribution of data at the upper or lower limits of the phenomenon's known (in this case artefactually recorded) range

claims.claim_text: OLE estimates likely become more accurate when samples display relatively low standard deviations, low kurtosis, and comparatively short distribution tails
claims.verbatim_quote: OLE estimates are, therefore, likely more accurate if samples display relatively low standard deviations, low kurtosis, and consequently comparatively short distribution tails

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Archaeological assemblages investigated in the case studies are sufficiently fragmentary to warrant OLE range extension, rather than already representing near-complete morphological ranges
trigger_text: The archaeological record is, however, fragmented and often provides a partial record of the total artefacts produced by a given population
Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper applies OLE to all case studies assuming fragmentariness without verifying degree of sampling for each assemblage. Whether Boxgrove (n=254 of ~500) or Sibudu (single layer) represent 'fragmentary' samples in the OLE-relevant sense is assumed rather than demonstrated.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Weibull-form distributions at morphological range tails are a reasonable assumption for cultural artefacts because cultural evolutionary pressures create preferential selection with variation introduced by external factors
trigger_text: This is a reasonable inference for most cultural artefacts governed by cultural evolutionary pressures, where specific object-forms are preferentially selected for, but variation is introduced to a sample by external factors including differing functional (incl. ecological) conditions, raw material factors, and drift mechanisms
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The Weibull distribution assumption is foundational to OLE validity. The paper asserts it is 'reasonable' for cultural artefacts but provides no empirical verification that archaeological morphometric distributions actually follow Weibull-form tails. This is treated as a theoretical given based on cultural evolutionary theory.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Replica stone tool assemblages produced by modern knappers adequately represent the morphological variation patterns of genuine archaeological assemblages for validation purposes
trigger_text: To circumnavigate this issue, we use modern assemblages of replica artefacts as this allows random subsamples from a much larger, known distribution of artefacts to be created
Two replica stone tool assemblages produced by the authors are used here, but the results can be applied within any type of material context
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Validation uses replicas made by two modern knappers (Key, Eren) as ground truth. The assumption that morphological variation patterns in modern experimental assemblages mirror those of prehistoric populations spanning 1.8 million years is unstated but essential to the validation logic.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: OLE range extensions indicate morphological diversity that genuinely existed in the past rather than model artefacts, measurement error, or outliers unrepresentative of the true population
trigger_text: In all instances artefact ranges were extended by the OLE estimates
there are likely far more diverse forms being produced by these H. heidelbergensis s.l. individuals than previously recognised
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper interprets all range extensions as indicating 'missing' past diversity. This bridges from OLE mathematical output to behavioural inference. The alternative interpretation—that range extensions reflect model sensitivity to outliers or assumption violations—is not systematically explored.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Archaeological artefacts within assemblages represent independent creative events suitable for OLE's independence assumption, even when produced by the same population or individual
trigger_text: OLE also assumes all investigated data to be independent. This is a straightforward assumption for most morphometric data, where each artefact represents a distinct creative process
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Cultural transmission and copying create dependencies between artefacts—a knapper's second handaxe is not independent of their first. The paper acknowledges industrial production may violate independence but assumes pre-industrial artefacts are independent, without addressing imitation and learning effects.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: All morphological forms within an artefact type's range had equal probability of preservation and discovery, so excavated samples represent unbiased draws from the original population
trigger_text: There is also the assumption that no portions of a given morphological range are more or less likely to be present in artefact assemblages. That is, all artefacts on a given morphological range are assumed to have been subject to the same rates of discovery
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Size-selective preservation and recovery biases are acknowledged for small artefacts (sieve mesh) but the equal-discovery assumption is maintained for case studies without verification. Larger or smaller artefacts may have systematically different survival rates due to fragility, curation, or visibility.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Validation results from two replica assemblages (handaxes n=500, archaic points n=45) generalise to the diverse archaeological case studies covering different materials, time periods, and production contexts
trigger_text: Two replica stone tool assemblages produced by the authors are used here, but the results can be applied within any type of material context
Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Validation uses lithic replicas but case studies include ceramics, metals, and non-human primate tools spanning 1.8 million years. The bridging claim that validation results 'can be applied within any type of material context' is asserted without demonstration that different materials/contexts produce comparable distribution properties.

research_designs.design_text: Repurposing Optimal Linear Estimation (OLE) modelling from temporal extinction studies for archaeological morphometric range estimation
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Here, we repurpose optimal linear estimation (OLE) modelling – which was originally developed to provide temporally bounded confidence intervals for species extinction events (Roberts and Solow, 2003) – to investigate how accurately it is able to identify the upper and lower limits of artefact morphological ranges from fragmentary archaeological records.
research_designs.design_rationale: OLE's proven ability to estimate temporal bounds from incomplete records provides theoretical basis for analogous application to morphometric bounds from fragmentary assemblages

research_designs.design_text: Blind test validation design using replica assemblages with known complete distributions as ground truth
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To circumnavigate this issue, we use modern assemblages of replica artefacts as this allows random subsamples from a much larger, known distribution of artefacts to be created. These subsamples are then used in an analogous way to the fragmentary portions of artefact records discovered by archaeologists, while the complete replica assemblage provides the 'truth' from which to assess the accuracy of the OLE model.
research_designs.design_rationale: Archaeological records cannot provide known 'true' morphological ranges, so replica assemblages with complete distributions enable validation against ground truth

research_designs.design_text: Multi-material case study design covering lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts across humans, extinct hominins, and non-human primates
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions (Fig. 2). Case studies cover tools produced or used by Holocene humans (Homo sapiens), Early-to-Late Pleistocene hominins (H. erectus, H. heidelbergensis s.l., Homo sapiens) and bearded capuchins (Sapajus libidinosus).
research_designs.design_rationale: Demonstrates method applicability across diverse archaeological contexts through breadth of case studies spanning 1.8 million years
expected_information_missing: Selection criteria for specific case studies
Rationale for specific time period coverage

research_designs.design_text: Weibull distribution assumption framework for morphometric range tails
research_designs.verbatim_quote: OLE assumes that the distribution of data at the upper or lower extreme of a given range follows a Weibull-form distribution. This is a reasonable inference for most cultural artefacts governed by cultural evolutionary pressures, where specific object-forms are preferentially selected for, but variation is introduced to a sample by external factors including differing functional (incl. ecological) conditions, raw material factors, and drift mechanisms.
research_designs.design_rationale: Theoretical justification for core statistical assumption based on cultural evolutionary theory
expected_information_missing: Empirical verification that archaeological distributions follow Weibull-form tails

research_designs.design_text: Independence assumption framework treating each artefact as distinct creative event
research_designs.verbatim_quote: OLE also assumes all investigated data to be independent. This is a straightforward assumption for most morphometric data, where each artefact represents a distinct creative process. In rare cases, assemblages may contain duplicate records (i.e. both halves of a broken artefact) although this is unlikely to significantly impact OLE estimates as any duplicates are likely to fall within the central range of a distribution (see supplementary table 3 for statistical data on distribution shapes).
research_designs.design_rationale: Justifies treatment of artefacts as independent observations despite potential cultural transmission dependencies
expected_information_missing: Discussion of imitation/learning effects on independence

research_designs.design_text: Equal discovery probability assumption across morphological range
research_designs.verbatim_quote: There is also the assumption that no portions of a given morphological range are more or less likely to be present in artefact assemblages. That is, all artefacts on a given morphological range are assumed to have been subject to the same rates of discovery. For archaeological finds, this might refer to preservation, excavation and/or taphonomy.
research_designs.design_rationale: Necessary assumption for unbiased range estimation; violations would introduce systematic bias
expected_information_missing: Verification of equal discovery rates for case study assemblages

methods.method_text: Random subsampling validation using known complete distributions to assess OLE accuracy
methods.verbatim_quote: The replica handaxe assemblage was randomly subsampled at rates of 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% relative to the total number of records in the assemblage. OLE estimates for the upper and lower morphological range limits of three variables were then computed from the k number of the extreme lower or upper values in that sample.

methods.method_text: Confidence interval coverage assessment comparing OLE estimates against known true values
methods.verbatim_quote: In addition to assessing the overall accuracy of OLE upper and lower range estimates (see Section 3.1.1), we also investigated confidence interval (CI) coverage for both replica assemblage types. CI coverage is defined as the proportion of all generated OLE confidence intervals that include the true value.

methods.method_text: Systematic k-value parameter testing across multiple values (5, 10, 20, 30)
methods.verbatim_quote: OLE estimates for the upper and lower morphological range limits of three variables were then computed from the k number of the extreme lower or upper values in that sample. All k values of 5, 10, 20 and 30 were tested.

methods.method_text: Iteration-based statistical analysis using 1000 iterations per parameter combination
methods.verbatim_quote: One thousand iterations of each process were performed for all subsampling percentages and k, and results were presented as median values across all iterations.
expected_information_missing: Justification for 1000 iterations vs other values

methods.method_text: Duplicate record handling through additional resampling procedures for geometric microliths
methods.verbatim_quote: Additional resampling procedures were undertaken for the geometric microliths to investigate the potential influence of duplicates on morphometric estimates. Here, when a typological duplicate was identified by the random resampling procedure that forms the basis of the OLE analysis (i.e. one part of a fragmented artefact), a new random artefact was drawn.

methods.method_text: Three-variable morphometric measurement approach (length/breadth/thickness or mass)
methods.verbatim_quote: The three morphometric variables investigated during validation tests on both assemblages were: length, breadth and thickness.
expected_information_missing: Measurement definitions and protocols for each variable

protocols.protocol_text: R version 4.3.0 software environment for all analyses
protocols.verbatim_quote: All analyses were undertaken in 'R' version 4.3.0 (R Core Team, 2023).

protocols.protocol_text: Random subsampling at 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% of total assemblage
protocols.verbatim_quote: The replica handaxe assemblage was randomly subsampled at rates of 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% relative to the total number of records in the assemblage.
procedure_steps: Randomly select records at specified percentage

protocols.protocol_text: k-values of 5, 10, 20, and 30 for OLE extreme value selection
protocols.verbatim_quote: OLE estimates for the upper and lower morphological range limits of three variables were then computed from the k number of the extreme lower or upper values in that sample. All k values of 5, 10, 20 and 30 were tested.

protocols.protocol_text: 1000 iterations per subsampling percentage and k-value combination
protocols.verbatim_quote: One thousand iterations of each process were performed for all subsampling percentages and k, and results were presented as median values across all iterations.

protocols.protocol_text: Archaic point adjusted sampling with 50% maximum due to small assemblage size (n=45)
protocols.verbatim_quote: For the archaic point assemblage, 50% was the maximum subsampling percentage used, as the small assemblage size (n = 45) prevented higher subsampling rates without falling below the minimum k value (i.e. k = 5).

protocols.protocol_text: CI coverage calculation as proportion of confidence intervals containing true value
protocols.verbatim_quote: A perfect coverage would be one that is equal to 1-alpha (with alpha of 0.05 used here). Coverage below 0.95 (0–0.94) indicates that OLE tends to underestimate the given morphological range limit, while values over 0.95 (0.96–1) indicate a tendency to overestimate.
procedure_steps: Generate OLE confidence interval for each iteration
Check if true value falls within confidence interval
Calculate proportion of intervals containing true value

protocols.protocol_text: Replica Acheulean handaxe production protocol using British flint over 18 months
protocols.verbatim_quote: 500 replica Acheulean handaxes were produced by Key and Lycett (2017) on British flint over the course of 18 months for use in a series of experimental functional studies (Key et al., 2020, 2023). All handaxes were produced by the first author of the present paper as part of their doctoral studies.

protocols.protocol_text: Early Archaic replica point production protocol using local cherts
protocols.verbatim_quote: These points, consistent with the Early Archaic side-notched 'Thebes cluster' style (Justice 1987), have not been used in any other published studies and were made by the co-author M. Eren for research purposes. They were produced on local cherts held by the Lithic Technology Laboratory, Kent State University, and are consistent in form with archaeological examples of Thebes Cluster points.

parameters.institutional_context: Kent State University Lithic Technology Laboratory

protocols.protocol_text: Archaic point measurement protocol using 2D digital imaging and image analysis
protocols.verbatim_quote: These points were measured using a 2D image analysis approach. Each point was photographed using a Canon T8i camera with a 100mm macro lens and lighting provided by a fluorescent light box. Photo files were loaded into ImageJ software and pixels converted to mm. Metrics of length, width, and thickness (TKNS) are taken from Buchanan et al. (2014).
procedure_steps: Photograph each point with Canon T8i camera

protocols.protocol_text: Microlith data filtering protocol combining completeness assessment and outlier removal
protocols.verbatim_quote: Given the above, we have only included geometrics with no evident breaks and retouching affecting no more than two margins in the sample. [...] As in the case of the main analysis, geometrics with values 3 standard deviations above the mean of a given variable were removed.
procedure_steps: Retain only pieces with no evident breaks
Retain only pieces with retouching on ≤2 margins
Calculate standard deviation for each variable
expected_information_missing: Whether lower bound outliers were also removed

consolidation_metadata.consolidation_rationale: Both protocols are data filtering steps for the same microlith assemblage, implement the same method (M005), and produce the same evidence (E012). Never cited independently.

protocols.protocol_text: Duplicate randomisation protocol for geometric microliths replacing duplicates with new random draws
protocols.verbatim_quote: Additional resampling procedures were undertaken for the geometric microliths to investigate the potential influence of duplicates on morphometric estimates. Here, when a typological duplicate was identified by the random resampling procedure that forms the basis of the OLE analysis (i.e. one part of a fragmented artefact), a new random artefact was drawn.
procedure_steps: Replace duplicates with new random draws
Compare results with and without duplicate removal

protocols.protocol_text: Gaussian kernel density estimation for visualising morphometric distributions
trigger_text: Gaussian kernel density distributions for each are also presented
protocols.inference_reasoning: Gaussian kernel density plots are shown in Figure 7 to visualise Paleoindian point distributions, but no protocol is documented in Methods specifying kernel bandwidth, software implementation, or procedure for generating these visualisations.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Kernel density estimation parameters not specified - unknown kernel bandwidth, smoothing parameters, or software used for Figure 7 visualisations
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Visualisation reproducibility limited without kernel specification

expected_information_missing: Software/R package used for kernel density estimation

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Methods paper. Archaeological case study data from previously published sources with permissions obtained by original researchers (noted in Acknowledgements for some datasets).

preregistration.notes: No preregistration mentioned. Methodological validation study.

references_completeness.notes: References section contains mix of DOI-available and older publications without DOIs. Estimated 40-60% of references have DOIs available.

F1_pid.rationale: Paper has DOI. Supplementary materials accessible via paper DOI.

F2_rich_metadata.rationale: No separate metadata record for code/data beyond paper abstract.

F4_indexed.rationale: Paper indexed in Web of Science, Scopus, Google Scholar.

I1_knowledge_representation.rationale: R scripts but no formal schema documentation.

I2_fair_vocabularies.rationale: No use of controlled vocabularies for metadata.

I3_qualified_references.rationale: No qualified links between datasets and code.

R1_2_provenance.rationale: Data sources documented in Methods section.

R1_3_community_standards.rationale: No use of community metadata standards (e.g., CodeMeta for software).

machine_actionability.rationale: Code and data in publisher supplementary materials. No dedicated repository, no separate DOIs, limited metadata.

discipline_context.era_label: FAIR and open science expectations established
discipline_context.baseline_expectations: Current-era papers expected to use dedicated repositories with DOIs for code/data. This paper meets minimum requirements (open access, code available) but falls short of best practices.
discipline_context.context_rationale: For a 2024 methods paper with R code, expected practice would be GitHub/Zenodo archiving with DOI. Supplementary-only provision is adequate but not optimal.

recommendations: Archive R scripts in dedicated repository (e.g., GitHub + Zenodo) with DOI
Create separate data package with DOI for morphometric datasets

extraction_metadata.notes: Methods paper with 12 authors. Strong funding acknowledgements with 8 distinct grants. Code available in supplementary but without dedicated repository. Open access CC BY. No ORCIDs found in PDF text. FAIR assessment shows moderately FAIR (60%) - meets accessibility requirements but lacks dedicated PIDs for code/data.

pass0_metadata.notes: 12-author methods paper. All author names extracted from title page with full given names. DOI present in header. Paper classified as methods paper based on explicit validation approach and case study structure.

pass6_infrastructure.notes: Code availability mentioned in methods text (pages 4, 6) but no formal statement section. Data availability via Appendix A reference only. Strong funding documentation with 8 grants. No ORCIDs in PDF. FAIR score 60% - accessible but limited interoperability.

pass1_evidence_claims.notes: Liberal extraction covering Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion. 34 evidence items capturing validation tests (E001-E006), case study samples (E007-E016), validation results (E017-E022), and case study findings (E023-E034). 24 claims spanning core methodological arguments (C001-C003), validation findings (C004-C009), case study interpretations (C010-C019), and theoretical arguments (C020-C024). 7 implicit arguments covering design assumptions (IA002, IA005, IA006), methodological assumptions (IA003), unstated assumptions (IA001), and bridging claims (IA004, IA007).

consolidations.rationale: All 8 case study sample size items had identical support pattern {C006} and are assessed together as evidence of methodological diversity

pass2_rationalisation.notes: Graph-based consolidation using identical support pattern analysis. 8 case study sample size items (E007-E010, E013-E016) consolidated into single E007 entry. Evidence IDs E011, E012, E017-E034 retained with original numbering (gaps in sequence). Claims and implicit arguments unchanged - already at appropriate assessment granularity.

pass3_rdmap_explicit.notes: Liberal explicit RDMAP extraction from Methods section (pages 2-9). Captured 6 research designs covering OLE repurposing framework, validation strategy, multi-material case study design, and three statistical assumptions (Weibull, independence, equal discovery). 6 methods covering validation, CI coverage, k-value testing, iteration analysis, duplicate handling, and morphometric measurement. 12 protocols with detailed specifications for software, sampling, parameters, production, measurement, and data filtering procedures.

pass4_rdmap_implicit.scan_methodology: Systematic 4-pattern scan for each RDMAP tier across each major section: (1) procedure mentioned without description, (2) effects implying undocumented causes, (3) tools mentioned without specifications, (4) strategic positioning without explicit statement

implicit_items.description: Gaussian kernel density estimation for visualising morphometric distributions

pass4_rdmap_implicit.assessment: Unusually low implicit ratio reflects exceptionally thorough Methods documentation in this methodological validation paper. The paper provides detailed protocols for all major procedures. Only kernel density visualisation (Figure 7) lacks parameter specification.
pass4_rdmap_implicit.notes: Conservative assessment after applying 4-pattern framework. Initial scan identified potential implicit methods (distribution shape analysis, correlation analysis) but these were interpretive observations in Results rather than distinct undocumented procedures. P-IMP-001 clearly qualifies as implicit protocol because kernel density is a specific visualisation technique used (Figure 7) but no parameters documented in Methods.

consolidations.rationale: Both data filtering protocols for microlith assemblage with identical support pattern (implement M005, produce E012). Combined completeness filter and outlier removal into single filtering protocol.

items_reviewed_not_consolidated.reason: Three model assumptions (Weibull, independence, equal discovery) serve distinct analytical purposes. RD005 specifically links to M005 for duplicate handling. Documented separately in paper.
Validation methods serve distinct functions (subsampling, CI coverage, k-testing, iterations) with separate protocols. Never consolidated in paper.
Different replica assemblage production protocols (handaxes vs archaic points) with different producers, materials, and contexts.

pass5_rdmap_rationalisation.notes: Reduction below 15-20% target (4%) justified by exceptionally thorough Methods documentation. Paper clearly separates distinct RDMAP items with different analytical purposes. Only P010+P011 met identical-support-pattern criteria for consolidation.
